bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James L. Hanberry, August 21, 1948

div1.p: Hench is sending Hanberry some photographs and returning Hanberry's news clippings.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James L. Hanberry, August 21, 1948
div1.opener:
August 21, 1948
Mr. J. L. Hanberry
Orangeburg
South Carolina
My dear Mr. Hanberry:
div1.p:
You must think me a most uncooperative individual but the truth is that
I have been just too busy this spring for my own good. I finally got the time to
have the photostats made and I am sending them to you by separate post, registered
mail. They include the snapshots which I took of you and your grandson, some nice
large photographs showing all of us on the platform at the meeting in Washington,
a couple of large photographs showing you taking a bow with General Reed beside
you, two photostatic positives and a photostatic negative of your fever chart
and some other items which I think you will enjoy. I am returning all of your
newspaper clippings and with most of them I am sending you for you to keep a nega-
tive photostat so that when anyone else asks you to borrow your clippings you will
not have to send them the originals.

I would greatly appreciate it if you would tell me from what paper and
about what date the following clippings were taken. I am sending a copy of this
letter so that you can just write after each heading what paper you think it is
from.
1. Clipping about Pinto's death.
2. Clipping about Kissinger's death.
3. Sontag's death. (Was his name spelled with two n's or one?
I have seen it both ways.)
4. Clipping about Folk's death. (I think this was the New York
Times, 1936, probably the 10th of February.)
5. “Yellow fever cause a war development” etc.
6. “Hero of Peace Crosses River”.
7. “Three Carolinians”
8. “Arlington Funeral” etc.

I am sending you a photostat of a clipping entitled “Due Recognition
Shown” etc. I had this clipping in my folder and I didn't know whether you had
given it to me but I believe you did not because it was already stamped “From
Gust Lambert” and that is the type of rubber stamp I have made for each man who
loans me or give me any clippings. I assume you have seen it but since you
didn't have it with your own clippings, I am sending you a positive photostat.
If, however, the original clipping is yours, please return the photostat and I
will send you the original.

Incidentally, if you want more of the large photos taken at the
Congress in Washington, I think you could probably get them by writing Mr.
Frank Standley, Office of Press Relations, Department of State, Washington, D. C.
Mr. J. L. Hanberry
- 2 -
August 21, 1948
They sent me a list of the photos taken at the Congress. The one of us on the
platform is 1376-88. The one of you standing up is 1376-93. In the identifi-
cation list which they sent me they didn't have the names quite correct. For
example, they identified General Reed as General Truby in the picture with you
and made the same mistake in the picture on the platform. I shall be glad
to know if these reach you safely.
Please give my best to your grandson.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
